newsitem.title: UK: UK petrol retailers say will raise prices quickly.
newsitem.headline: UK petrol retailers say will raise prices quickly.

text.p: British motorists may be spared higher petrol prices for a couple of days but most leading retailers including oil companies and supermarket chains said on Wednesday they would have little choice but to rapidly pass to customers new UK excise duties.
British finance minister Gordon Brown said he would raise road fuel duties to six percent above the rate of inflation increasing the price of petrol by four pence a litre effective immediately
British Petroleum Plc said it would be raising prices for petrol and diesel but not immediately.
"We will hold them for as long as we can but it won't be for long," a BP spokesman said.
Supermarket chain J. Sainsbury Plc said it hoped to keep prices at current levels for "a couple of days".

U.K. market leader Esso, whose PriceWatch campaign has been blamed for a fierce turf war which helped shut 1,500 petrol stations in 1996, said it would remain competitive, matching the lowest prices at supermarkets within a three-mile radius and at other retailers within a one-mile radius.
"We will closely monitor the market and if it moves up we will move up with it," a spokesman said.

The price war has slashed retail petrol margins to among the lowest in Europe. Major oil companies in Britain's refining and marketing industry lost 110 million sterling ($184 million) in 1996 following a pre-tax profit of 94 million sterling in 1995.
